channel.title: Talks By Dallin H. Oaks
channel.description: General Conference talks by Dallin H. Oaks.

item.title: Strive for Excellence
item.description: My beloved brethren who hold the priesthood of God: Over the past several months I have had occasion to ponder the problems and to reflect upon the ideals of education in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. As I have studied this subject

item.title: Why Do We Serve?
item.description: My dear brothers and sisters, because it was not appropriate for me to commence my Church service until I had concluded my judicial duties in state government, I did not speak at the April conference where I was sustained. Consequently, this semiannu

item.title: Taking upon Us the Name of Jesus Christ
item.description: On this Easter Sunday we rejoice in the resurrection of our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ. This is a holy day for all of Christianity. Countless Christians attend worship services on this day to partake of the sacrament of the Lord’s Supper, which ma

item.title: Spirituality
item.description: As faithful members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, we have a distinctive way of looking at life. We view our experiences in terms of eternity. As we draw farther from worldliness, we feel closer to our Father in Heaven and more a

item.title: Reverent and Clean
item.description: Recently our family was viewing what was supposed to be a wholesome movie on videotape. Suddenly, one of the actors used a vulgar expression. Embarrassed, we began to smooth this over for our ten-year-old daughter. She quickly assured us that we need

item.title: “Brother’s Keeper”
item.description: One of the consequences of mortality is the necessity of earning our daily bread (see ; ). We do so as employees, as business people, and as investors. In all of our earning activities, we have the challenge of dealing fairly and considerately with o

item.title: Priesthood Blessings
item.description: In the spring of 1866, during what is called the Black Hawk War, our pioneers were struggling to beat back deadly Indian attacks on many settlements in southern Utah. Two of President Heber C. Kimball’s sons were called into military service for a th

item.title: “The Light and Life of the World”
item.description: My dear brothers and sisters, I rejoice with you in the privilege of coming together on this beautiful Sabbath day to worship our Father in Heaven and his Son Jesus Christ and to be instructed by their servants.

item.title: Always Remember Him
item.description: In April 1830 the Lord commanded the members of his newly restored Church to “meet together often to partake of bread and wine in the remembrance of the Lord Jesus” (). This was the same instruction he gave when he introduced this ordinance nearly 2,

item.title: “What Think Ye of Christ?”
item.description: “What think ye of Christ?” (.) That question is as penetrating today as when Jesus used it to confound the Pharisees almost two thousand years ago. Like a sword, sharp and powerful, it uncovers what is hidden, divides truth from error, and goes to th

item.title: Alternate Voices
item.description: Last summer, at a Pioneer parade in Wyoming, I saw a young colt separated from its mother. The lost youngster whinnied and trotted about, listening to a chorus of voices as it sought the voice that would guide it back to the side of the one it loved.

item.title: Modern Pioneers
item.description: The days of the pioneers are not past. There are modern pioneers whose achievements are an inspiration to all of us.

item.title: World Peace
item.description: Some years ago, an acquaintance of mine who was moving to Washington, D.C., went to the district offices to take the driver’s license examination. He had to fill out a form that asked for his business address and his occupation. He had just been appo

item.title: Witnesses of Christ
item.description: A few months ago, I received a letter from a Church member who posed an unusual question: “Do I have a right to bear testimony of the Savior? Or is that the sole prerogative of the Twelve?” In response, I will share some thoughts on why every member

item.title: “Honour Thy Father and Thy Mother”
item.description: Since our conference last October, many have ridden roller coasters of emotion from the war in the Persian Gulf. Many Latter-day Saints had their lives changed by that conflict. In the military theater of operations, we had over 140 Latter-day Saint

item.title: Joy and Mercy
item.description: One of the greatest of all God’s revelations is Father Lehi’s teaching that “men are, that they might have joy.” (.) Joy is more than happiness. Joy is the ultimate sensation of well-being. It comes from being complete and in harmony with our Creator

item.title: The Relief Society and the Church
item.description: This year we are celebrating the 150th anniversary of the Relief Society, organized in Nauvoo, Illinois, on March 17, 1842. Last month’s anniversary program was carried by satellite to most continents of the world. Books are being published to review

item.title: Bible Stories and Personal Protection
item.description: My dear brethren, this is an important occasion, when holders of the holy priesthood all over the world gather for instruction and inspiration.

item.title: The Language of Prayer
item.description: When I was young, I learned that great respect was owed to those who held the office of bishop. As a sign of that respect, we always addressed our bishop as “Bishop Christensen” or “Bishop Calder” or “Brother Jones.” We never called our bishop “Mr.”

item.title: “The Great Plan of Happiness”
item.description: Questions like, Where did we come from? Why are we here? and Where are we going? are answered in the gospel of Jesus Christ. Prophets have called it the plan of salvation and “the great plan of happiness” (). Through inspiration we can understand thi

item.title: “Faith in the Lord Jesus Christ”
item.description: My beloved young sisters, I have been inspired by the prayers, music, and words in this marvelous meeting. I feel that each young woman who is listening has been strengthened in her resolve to become what President Janette C. Hales has challenged her

item.title: Tithing
item.description: When the risen Lord appeared to the faithful on this continent, he taught them the commandments the prophet Malachi had already given to other children of Israel. The Lord commanded that they should record these words (see ).

item.title: Worship through Music
item.description: President Hunter, we have been thrilled by your inspired message. We express our love to you. We also congratulate the newly called and sustained General Authorities and general officers of the Church.

item.title: Apostasy and Restoration
item.description: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has many beliefs in common with other Christian churches. But we have differences, and those differences explain why we send missionaries to other Christians, why we build temples in addition to churche

item.title: Powerful Ideas
item.description: Last summer I attended the funeral of an elect lady. One speaker described three of her great qualities: loyalty, obedience, and faith. As he elaborated on her life, I thought how appropriate it was to speak of such powerful qualities in a funeral tr

item.title: Joseph, the Man and the Prophet
item.description: On this beautiful Easter Sunday, I have chosen to speak about the Prophet Joseph Smith, and to emphasize some lesser-known aspects of his life that further affirm his prophetic calling.

item.title: “Always Have His Spirit”
item.description: I have chosen to speak about the relationship between our partaking of the sacrament and our enjoying the blessings available from the gift of the Holy Ghost.

item.title: “Bishop, Help!”
item.description: The burden [of a bishop] is a heavy one that cannot be fulfilled without the supportive efforts of ward officers and members.

item.title: Following the Pioneers
item.description: Do you, like the pioneers, have the courage and the consistency to be true to the faith and endure to the end?

item.title: Have You Been Saved?
item.description: As Latter-day Saints use the words saved and salvation, there are at least six different meanings.

item.title: The Aaronic Priesthood and the Sacrament
item.description: Those who hold the Aaronic Priesthood open the door for all Church members who worthily partake of the sacrament to enjoy the companionship of the Spirit of the Lord and the ministering of angels.

item.title: The Witness: Martin Harris
item.description: One of Martin Harris’s greatest contributions to the Church, for which he should be honored for all time, was his financing the publication of the Book of Mormon.

item.title: Gospel Teaching
item.description: In our sacred callings of gospel teaching, no effort is too good for the work of the Lord and the growth of His children.

item.title: Resurrection
item.description: Resurrection is much more than merely reuniting a spirit to a body. … The resurrection is a restoration that brings back “carnal for carnal” and “good for that which is good” (Alma 41:13).

item.title: The Challenge to Become
item.description: In contrast to the institutions of the world, which teach us to know something, the gospel of Jesus Christ challenges us to become something.

item.title: Focus and Priorities
item.description: Available information wisely used is far more valuable than multiplied information allowed to lie fallow.

item.title: Sharing the Gospel
item.description: The most effective missionaries, member and full-time, always act out of love. … If we lack this love for others, we should pray for it.

item.title: The Gospel in Our Lives
item.description: He has given us His Atonement, His gospel, and His Church, a sacred combination that gives us the assurance of immortality and the opportunity for eternal life.

item.title: I’ll Go Where You Want Me to Go
item.description: The full measure of [our] conversion to men and women of God happens best through our labors in His vineyard.

item.title: Give Thanks in All Things
item.description: When we give thanks in all things, we see hardships and adversities in the context of the purpose of life.

item.title: Repentance and Change
item.description: Repenting means giving up all of our practices—personal, family, ethnic, and national—that are contrary to the commandments of God.

item.title: Preparation for the Second Coming
item.description: We need to make … spiritual preparation for the events prophesied at the time of the Second Coming.

item.title: Be Not Deceived
item.description: The Holy Ghost will protect us against being deceived, but to realize that wonderful blessing we must always do the things necessary to retain that Spirit.

item.title: Pornography
item.description: Let us all improve our personal behavior and redouble our efforts to protect our loved ones and our environment from the onslaught of pornography.

item.title: Priesthood Authority in the Family and the Church
item.description: There are many similarities and some differences in the way priesthood authority functions in the family and in the Church.

item.title: All Men Everywhere
item.description: Again and again the Book of Mormon teaches that the gospel of Jesus Christ is universal in its promise and effect.

item.title: He Heals the Heavy Laden
item.description: The healing power of the Lord Jesus Christ … is available for every affliction in mortality.

item.title: Divorce
item.description: A good marriage does not require a perfect man or a perfect woman. It only requires a man and a woman committed to strive together toward perfection.

item.title: Good, Better, Best
item.description: We have to forego some good things in order to choose others that are better or best because they develop faith in the Lord Jesus Christ and strengthen our families.

item.title: Testimony
item.description: Knowledge encourages obedience, and obedience enhances knowledge.

item.title: Sacrament Meeting and the Sacrament
item.description: The ordinance of the sacrament makes the sacrament meeting the most sacred and important meeting in the Church.

item.title: Unselfish Service
item.description: Our Savior teaches us to follow Him by making the sacrifices necessary to lose ourselves in unselfish service to others.

item.title: Love and Law
item.description: The love of God does not supersede His laws and His commandments, and the effect of God’s laws and commandments does not diminish the purpose and effect of His love.

item.title: Healing the Sick
item.description: We have this priesthood power, and we should all be prepared to use it properly.

item.title: Two Lines of Communication
item.description: We must use both the personal line and the priesthood line in proper balance to achieve the growth that is the purpose of mortal life.

item.title: Desire
item.description: To achieve our eternal destiny, we will desire and work for the qualities required to become an eternal being.

item.title: Teachings of Jesus
item.description: Jesus Christ is the Only Begotten and Beloved Son of God. … He is our Savior from sin and death. This is the most important knowledge on earth.

item.title: Sacrifice
item.description: Our lives of service and sacrifice are the most appropriate expressions of our commitment to serve the Master and our fellowmen.

item.title: Protect the Children
item.description: None should resist the plea that we unite to increase our concern for the welfare and future of our children—the rising generation.

item.title: Followers of Christ
item.description: Following Christ is not a casual or occasional practice but a continuous commitment and way of life that applies at all times and in all places.

item.title: No Other Gods
item.description: Are we serving priorities or gods ahead of the God we profess to worship?

item.title: The Keys and Authority of the Priesthood
item.description: Dallin H. Oaks teaches how men and women, though they have different roles, serve and are blessed on the same terms through the priesthood.

item.title: Loving Others and Living with Differences
item.description: Dallin H. Oaks teaches that as disciples of Jesus Christ, we are to love others and live peacefully with those whose beliefs differ from our own.

item.title: The Parable of the Sower
item.description: Dallin H. Oaks discusses the parable of the sower and warns of attitudes that prevent the word of God from growing in our hearts and bearing "fruit."

item.title: Strengthened by the Atonement of Jesus Christ
item.description: Dallin H. Oaks testifies of the power of Christ’s Atonement to strengthen and help us in the pains, afflictions, and infirmities of mortality.

item.title: Sharing the Restored Gospel
item.description: Elder Oaks teaches that sharing the gospel is a joyful privilege and provides ideas to help members fulfill this responsibility effectively.

item.title: The Godhead and the Plan of Salvation
item.description: Elder Oaks teaches that because we know the truth about the Godhead and the plan of salvation, we have the road map for our mortal journey.
